Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, which guarantees that a tenant shall be free from substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of the leased premises by the landlord.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186 (landlord-tenant.proposition: Massachusetts law and the State Sanitary Code further recognize that landlords must provide and maintain premises in a condition fit for human habitation and free from conditions (such as persistent leaks and mold) that substantially interfere with safe occupancy.

Sommer v. Kridel, 456 N.E.2d 806 (N.Y. 1.support_reasoning: The claimed proposition is essentially a placeholder (“legal principles pleaded above”) and gives no specific rule or issue to compare against the opinion. The opinion itself deals with a criminal plea, the court’s inherent power to vacate pleas/sentences, and double jeopardy, which appears unrelated to any articulated civil or other ‘legal principles’ in the provided text. Without a concrete proposition, there is no clear match between this case and the claimed support.
Sommer v. Kridel, 456 N.E.2d 806 (N.Y. 1.relevant_excerpt: “After sentence has commenced, a court which has accepted a plea in violation of the Criminal Procedure Law may not vacate the illegal plea and reinstate the original charges… There being no basis for the court’s vacatur of the plea, the original plea and sentence must be reinstated, and further criminal proceedings on the first felony charges are barred by double jeopardy protection.”
